title: Platform Migration — Monolith to Microservices
summary: Decomposing the Rails monolith into domain-driven microservices. Phase 2 in progress: extracting the Billing domain — the most coupled service with 40+ DB joins and a 50M-row backfill.
body: The platform migration breaks the monolith into six bounded contexts: Auth, Billing, Notifications, Search, Content, and Analytics. Phase 1 (complete) extracted Auth into a Go service behind an API gateway. Phase 2 (in progress) targets Billing — the most coupled domain with ~40 direct DB joins to other tables. Key risks: data consistency during dual-write period, latency increase from network hops, and team ramp-up on new service ownership model. Target: all services independent by Q3.

title: Mobile App v2 — React Native Rewrite
summary: Replacing native iOS/Android apps with a unified React Native codebase. Core navigation and auth complete; dashboard and real-time features in progress. Targeting 60fps on mid-range Android.
body: Mobile App v2 replaces separate Swift and Kotlin codebases with a single React Native app. Architecture: Expo managed workflow, React Navigation v7, Zustand for state, and a shared design system. Current status: core navigation and auth flows complete, working on the dashboard and real-time features. Performance target: 60fps on mid-range Android devices. Marcus is leading the effort and is currently debugging animation jank on the transaction list screen.

title: Shared Design System — Cross-Platform Component Library
summary: 42-component library shared across web and mobile. Built with Storybook, design tokens from Figma, WCAG 2.1 AA accessibility, and visual regression testing via Chromatic.
body: The design system provides a single source of truth for UI components across web (React) and mobile (React Native). Key pieces: (1) Design tokens for color, spacing, and typography — synced from Figma via Style Dictionary. (2) 42 production components including Button, Modal, DataTable, and Toast. (3) Accessibility: all components meet WCAG 2.1 AA — automated axe checks in CI. (4) Visual regression tests via Chromatic catch unintended style changes. Current focus: dark mode support and right-to-left (RTL) layout variants. Priya is coordinating the Figma-to-code token pipeline with the design team.

title: Customer Onboarding Redesign — Guided Setup Flow
summary: New 5-step onboarding wizard replacing the self-serve flow. A/B test (n=2,400) shows 34% lift in Day-7 activation and 13pp retention improvement. Shipping to 100% next sprint.
body: Current onboarding drops 62% of users before completing setup. Pain points identified via FullStory: (1) users skip the integration step, (2) team invitation flow is confusing, (3) no progress indicator. New design: 5-step wizard — Profile → Integrations → Team Invite → First Project → Dashboard Tour. Each step has contextual help and a 'skip for now' option. A/B test results (n=2,400): Day-1 activation 78% vs 61% (control), Day-7 retention 52% vs 39%. Plan: ship to 100% of new signups next sprint, then iterate on the integration step which still has highest drop-off. Marcus is building the mobile variant and Priya owns the success metrics.

title: API Gateway — Kong vs Envoy Benchmark
summary: Envoy benchmarks at 8ms P95 vs Kong's 45ms. Root causes: Kong's plugin chain adds 30ms and upstream DNS adds 15ms. Recommendation: migrate to Envoy with sidecar rate-limiting.
body: Current API gateway (Kong 3.4) routes traffic to 12 upstream services. Performance breakdown: plugin chain (auth + rate-limit + logging) adds ~30ms, DNS resolution for upstream services adds ~15ms. Proposed fixes: (1) switch to DNS caching with 10s TTL, (2) move rate-limiting to a dedicated sidecar to parallelize with auth, (3) evaluate switching to Envoy for lower per-request overhead. Sarah has benchmarked Envoy and sees 8ms P95 vs Kong's 45ms, but migration effort is significant. Decision needed by end of sprint.

title: Billing Database Migration — Dual-Write Strategy
summary: Migrating billing data (50M rows) to a dedicated service DB via dual-write → backfill → shadow-read → cutover. 40+ foreign keys become API calls. Backfill estimated at 6–8 hours.
body: Migration approach: (1) Create new billing_service DB with clean schema. (2) Implement dual-write layer that writes to both old and new DBs. (3) Backfill historical data (~50M rows). (4) Run shadow reads comparing old vs new for 2 weeks. (5) Cut over reads to new DB. (6) Remove dual-write after 30-day soak. Key concern: the billing tables have 40+ foreign key relationships to other domains — these become API calls in the new world. Estimated backfill time: 6-8 hours with batched inserts. Sarah is drafting the rollback plan.

title: React Native — Transaction List Performance Fix
summary: Transaction list drops to 42fps due to JS-driven animations blocking the bridge. Fix: migrate to Reanimated 3 worklets (UI thread), memo list items, and add FastImage disk caching.
body: Performance profiling revealed the transaction list FlatList re-renders cause frame drops during scroll animations. Root causes: (1) JS-driven Animated API blocks the bridge during heavy list updates. (2) Inline styles cause unnecessary re-renders. (3) Large images not cached properly. Fixes in progress: (1) Migrate all animations to Reanimated 3 worklets (UI thread). (2) Extract list items into React.memo components with stable keys. (3) Implement FastImage with disk caching. Marcus expects 60fps after these changes — currently at 42fps on Pixel 6.

title: Search Infrastructure — Elasticsearch to Typesense Migration
summary: Replacing self-managed Elasticsearch (12ms avg, $2k/mo) with Typesense Cloud (4ms avg, $800/mo). Dual-indexing live; A/B routing 10% traffic. Measuring relevance parity via NDCG scores.
body: Current Elasticsearch cluster: 3 nodes, 12 shards, ~200GB index. Pain points: frequent OOM during peak indexing, manual shard rebalancing, and JVM tuning overhead. Typesense evaluation: (1) Query latency: 4ms avg vs ES's 12ms. (2) Indexing speed: 15k docs/sec vs ES's 5k. (3) Cost: $800/mo managed vs $2,000/mo self-hosted ES. Migration plan: dual-index for 2 weeks, A/B route 10% traffic to Typesense, measure relevance parity via NDCG scores, then full cutover. Status: dual indexing pipeline built, A/B routing in progress. Sarah is handling the backend integration.

title: Q1 Security Audit — Critical Findings & Remediation
summary: Pen test found 2 critical issues: (1) JWT tokens valid after password reset (24h window), (2) IDOR on billing invoice endpoints. Plus 5 medium findings. Remediation deadline: March 15.
body: Audit conducted by SecureTech Partners, Jan 15–Feb 5. Scope: API endpoints, auth flows, and data storage. Critical findings: (1) JWT tokens remain valid after password reset — users who change passwords are still vulnerable until token expires (24h). Fix: add token generation timestamp to JWT claims, invalidate on password change. (2) Insecure direct object reference on /api/billing/invoices/:id — any authenticated user can access other users' invoices by guessing IDs. Fix: add ownership check middleware. Medium findings include missing rate limits on login (fixed), verbose error messages leaking stack traces (fixed), and missing CSP headers (in progress). Priya is tracking remediation status against the March 15 deadline.

title: Analytics Pipeline — Event Tracking Overhaul
summary: Replacing Segment ($4.5k/mo, 8% event loss) with first-party SDK → Kafka → Snowflake + dbt. Zero event loss, enforced schema via Protobuf, cost down to $1.2k/mo. Mobile SDK in progress.
body: Current issues with Segment pipeline: (1) 8% event drop rate during peak traffic. (2) Schema drift — 30+ undocumented event types. (3) $4,500/mo cost for Segment + BigQuery. New architecture: first-party JS/RN SDK → Kafka → Snowflake, with dbt models for metrics. Benefits: zero event loss (Kafka durability), enforced schema registry (Protobuf), cost down to ~$1,200/mo. Migration timeline: SDK shipped (web done, mobile in progress), Kafka pipeline live, dbt models 60% complete. Key risk: historical data in BigQuery needs replayed into Snowflake for year-over-year comparisons. Sarah is building the Kafka consumers, Marcus owns the mobile SDK integration.

title: CI/CD Pipeline — Build Time Optimization
summary: CI pipeline averages 22 min. Target: under 8 min via parallel test shards, dependency caching, and a persistent test DB. Biggest win: GitHub Actions matrix cuts test time from 15 min to 3 min.
body: Current pipeline: lint (2min) → unit tests (8min) → integration tests (7min) → build (3min) → deploy (2min). Bottlenecks: (1) Tests run sequentially — splitting into parallel shards could cut test time to 3min. (2) No dependency caching — npm install takes 90s each run. (3) Integration tests spin up full Docker compose stack every time — could use persistent test environment. Proposed changes: GitHub Actions matrix strategy for test shards, artifact caching for node_modules and Docker layers, and a pre-provisioned test database.

title: Incident Postmortem — Feb 18 API Outage (30 min)
summary: 30-min outage from DB connection pool exhaustion. Root cause: billing reconciliation query held 15 connections for 8+ minutes during a traffic spike. Fix: paginate queries, per-service pool limits, circuit breakers.
body: Timeline: 14:02 — alerts fire for 5xx spike. 14:05 — on-call confirms API returning 503s. 14:12 — identified DB connection pool at 100% utilization. 14:18 — killed the long-running billing reconciliation query. 14:22 — connections freed, API recovering. 14:32 — fully recovered. Root cause: billing reconciliation job (runs hourly) executed a query scanning 2M rows without pagination, holding 15 connections for 8+ minutes. During a concurrent traffic spike, remaining pool exhausted. Fix: (1) paginate reconciliation query, (2) add connection pool limits per service, (3) add circuit breaker for DB connections.

title: GitHub — RN FlatList lazy renderItem init (#55027)
summary: Public RN performance request proposing lazy/progressive initialization for complex FlatList renderItem trees to improve perceived mount performance.
body: Summary: Issue proposes a lazy/progressive rendering pattern for FlatList items so initial mount doesn't eagerly construct complex renderItem trees. The idea is similar to rendering placeholders first then hydrating full content after the first frame, improving perceived performance on mid-range devices. Relevance to our Mobile v2 list jank: if our stutter is dominated by renderItem closure churn + expensive mount work, we can mimic this locally with staged rendering (skeleton -> hydrate), reduce initialNumToRender, memoize item subtrees, and avoid allocating large object graphs during refresh.

title: GitHub — useDeferredValue stuck stale (#35821)
summary: Public React bug report where useDeferredValue can get stuck and never catch up (observed more frequently in prod builds).
body: Summary: Bug report describes useDeferredValue getting stuck on a stale value, especially in production builds, in a repro involving rendering JSX from a server action and resolving promises inside Suspense. A workaround mentioned is forcing periodic re-renders (e.g., a ticker) to unstick the tree, but that is not ideal. Relevance: if our app uses deferred rendering or promise-based UI updates, this issue is a reminder to validate behavior in prod builds and to keep a simple fallback path when 'deferred' UI fails to converge.

title: GitHub — Next.js Router Cache misses w/ search params (#90008)
summary: Public Next.js issue: Router Cache misses on every navigation when <Link> href includes search params in 15.x; workaround is forcing FULL prefetch.
body: Summary: Report claims that for static pages linked with query params (tabs/filters), client navigations miss the Router Cache every time in Next.js 15.x, leading to repeated RSC fetches. The issue hypothesizes a mismatch between AUTO prefetch cache key (pathname only) and navigation cache key (pathname + params), causing misses. Workaround: set prefetch={true} on Links that include search params so the prefetch entry keys with params from the start.

title: GitHub — /_next/data missing Content-Length since 15.4.1 (#90281)
summary: Public Next.js regression: /_next/data JSON responses switch to chunked transfer (no Content-Length/ETag) since 15.4.1, breaking CDN compression behaviors.
body: Summary: Report describes a regression where /_next/data JSON responses become streaming (Transfer-Encoding: chunked) and omit Content-Length/ETag after upgrading from 15.4.0 to 15.4.1. For self-hosters behind CloudFront, this prevents edge compression because CloudFront requires Content-Length to compress origin responses. The report points to a template change that wraps JSON in Buffer.from(...), making the response appear 'dynamic' to RenderResult and skipping header generation. Relevance: if we self-host or rely on CDN compression, we should validate headers after upgrades and include regression checks for response metadata.

title: AmbientKnowledge Example — Project Handoff
summary: A sender can attach a crisp project brief (status, risks, owners, links) so the recipient can act immediately without asking for background.
body:
Scenario: An engineer asks someone to take over a migration or on-call action item mid-sprint.

Pain without AmbientKnowledge: The recipient replies with 'what's the status, where's the doc, what's risky?' and the thread turns into a scavenger hunt.

What the Context Card should surface:
- Current phase + what 'done' means
- Top 2 risks + mitigations
- Primary owner(s) and who to ping
- One canonical doc link

Example message: 'Can you take point on Billing extraction kickoff next week?'
Example attached context: 'Billing migration is in dual-write/backfill planning; main risks are DB pool saturation during backfill + latency from FK→RPC swaps; rollback plan draft exists; next step is write one-pager plan + API stubs.'

title: AmbientKnowledge Example — Code Review Context
summary: Reviewers get the 'why' (constraints, prior decisions, rollout plan) attached inline, reducing round trips and preventing bikeshedding.
body:
Scenario: A PR touches a sensitive area (gateway rollout, perf regression, security remediation).

Pain without AmbientKnowledge: Reviewers ask the same questions: why this approach, what metrics matter, what's the rollback, what prior decision are we following. The author re-pastes context into multiple threads.

What the Context Card should surface:
- The decision already made (e.g., opt-in first week + allowlist)
- Expected metrics and guardrails
- Rollback/runbook link
- Related upstream issue(s) if behavior depends on framework/runtime bugs

Example: A PR that changes response handling after a Next.js upgrade. The card can include a known upstream regression issue and the local mitigation plan so reviewers focus on correctness and safety.

title: AmbientKnowledge Example — Incident Bridge & Triage
summary: When someone joins an incident mid-stream, a one-click context card provides the timeline, hypotheses, and current mitigation so they can help immediately.
body:
Scenario: A new engineer joins an active incident thread or the on-call handoff happens between time zones.

Pain without AmbientKnowledge: The thread contains 60+ messages. New joiners ask for a recap, slowing the people actively debugging.

What the Context Card should surface:
- One-sentence problem statement
- Current impact + scope
- What we've tried + what worked
- Current mitigation and owners
- Link to the postmortem template or prior similar incident

Outcome: New joiners can take a parallel task (logs, repro, comms) without disrupting the primary responders.

title: AmbientKnowledge Example — Cross-Team / Org Merge
summary: When teams collaborate (or merge), context cards prevent mismatched assumptions by attaching shared definitions and interface contracts to messages.
body:
Scenario: Two teams coordinate a multi-quarter migration (gateway rollout, billing extraction) or a newly merged org is aligning on a shared roadmap.

Pain without AmbientKnowledge: Each team has its own 'source of truth'. Decisions get re-litigated; names and timelines drift; ownership is unclear.

What the Context Card should surface:
- Shared milestones + dates
- Interface contracts (API names, compatibility constraints)
- The canonical doc(s)
- Who is DRI for each milestone

Outcome: Messages become self-contained and portable across channels, so new stakeholders can evaluate decisions without digging through old threads.

title: AmbientKnowledge Example — New Hire / New Team Onboarding
summary: New team members can click 'What's this about?' on jargon-heavy messages and immediately see definitions, owners, and links.
body:
Scenario: A new hire is added to a channel like #platform-migration or #release-train. Messages reference internal nouns ('dual-write', 'shadow read', 'go/no-go', 'allowlist') and prior decisions.

Pain without AmbientKnowledge: The new hire DMs someone for context or silently misses nuance, causing accidental rework.

What the Context Card should surface:
- Definitions of key terms in this org
- Current status + what decisions are locked
- Links to 1-2 canonical docs
- Who to ask for what (owner mapping)

Outcome: Faster ramp with less social overhead, and less risk of repeating already-settled decisions.
